source.917cd41b:
#starting by importing some important libraries
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import numpy as np
import plotly.express as px

data = pd.read_csv("../input/water-potability/water_potability.csv")
data.head()
source.1c5e89ae:
#before moving ahead let's remove the rows containing null values
data = data.dropna()
data.isnull().sum()
source.efecf1ee:
plt.figure(figsize=(15, 10))
sns.countplot(data.Potability)
plt.title("Distribution of Unsafe and Safe Water")
plt.show()
source.e1d8d77d:
#now let's explore all the columns one by one 
#import plotly.express as px
data = data
figure = px.histogram(data, x = "ph",
                     color = "Potability",
                     title = "Fators Affecting Water Quality: PH")
figure.show()
"""the ph value of drinking water should be between 6.5 and 8.5."""
source.7af3ea5e:
#we've seen ph value and let's see Hardness of the water
figure = px.histogram(data, x = "Hardness",
                     color = "Potability",
                     title = "Factors Affecting Water Quality: Hardness")
figure.show()
# figure show the distribution of water hardness in the dataset. The hardness of water usually depends on its source, but water with a hardness of 120-200 miligrams is drinkable.
source.d5e86e51:
#let's see another column solids
figure = px.histogram(data, x = "Solids",
                     color = "Potability",
                     title = "Factors Affecting Water Quality: Solids")
figure.show()
"""The figure represents the distribution of total dissolved solid in water in the dataset. All organic and inorganic minerals presents in the 
water are called dissolved solids. Water with a very high number of dissolved solids. Water with a very high number of dissolved solids is highly mineralized."""
source.911e4231:
#Column: Chloramines
figure = px.histogram(data, x="Chloramines",
                     color = "Potability",
                     title = "Factor Affecting Wter Quality: Chloramines")
figure.show()
"""This figure represents the distribution of chloramine in water in the dataset."""
source.5bbfae7a:
#column: sulfate
figure = px.histogram(data, x="Sulfate",
                     color = "Potability",
                     title = "Factor Affecting Wter Quality: Sulfate")
figure.show()
"""The figure shows the distribution of sulfate in water in the dataset. Water containing less thtan 500 miligrams of sulfate is safe to drink."""
source.1378d749:
#column: Conductivity
figure = px.histogram(data, x="Conductivity",
                     color = "Potability",
                     title = "Factor Affecting Wter Quality: Conductivity")
figure.show()
"""Water is a good conductor of elecrity, but the purest form of water is not a good conductor of electricity.
Water with an electrical conductivity of less than 500 is drinkable."""
source.75243045:
#column: Carbon
figure = px.histogram(data, x="Organic_carbon",
                     color = "Potability",
                     title= "Factors Affecting Water Quality: Organic Carbon")
figure.show()
"""Figure showing the distribution of orgainc water in the dataset. Organic Carbon comes from the breakdown of natural organic materials and synthetic sources. 
Water containing less than 25 miligrams of orgainc carbon is considered safe to drink"""
source.6bfafa0b:
#column: Trihalomethanes
figure = px.histogram(data, x = "Trihalomethanes", 
                      color = "Potability", 
                      title= "Factors Affecting Water Quality: Trihalomethanes")
figure.show()
"""The figure represens the distribution of trihalomethanes in the water.
THMs are chemicals found in chlorine treates water. Water contianing less than 80 miligrams of THMs is considered safe to drink."""
source.95382f50:
#Column: Turbidity
figure = px.histogram(data, x = "Turbidity", 
                      color = "Potability", 
                      title= "Factors Affecting Water Quality: Turbidity")
figure.show()
"""The trubidity of water depends on the number of solids present in suspension. Water with a trubidity a fewer than 5 milligrams is considered drinkable"""
source.9917ec2a:
from pycaret.classification import *
clf = setup(data, target = "Potability", silent = True, session_id = 786)
compare_models()
source.95b7c44f:
model = create_model("rf")
predict = predict_model(model, data=data)
predict.head()
source.2a7d8773: The potability column of this dataset is the column we need to predict because it contains values 0 and 1 that indicate whether the water is potable(1) and unfit(0) for consumption. So let's see the distribution of 0 and 1 in the Potability column:
